raw_text:
Brown 'proud of economy record'
 
 Gordon Brown has delivered a rousing speech to Labour's spring conference setting out the government's agenda for the next general election.
 
 The chancellor said he was proud of his party's record on the economy, and would strive for continuing stability if elected. The Gateshead conference was told he would help young people who were struggling to buy their own homes. And the chancellor vowed to continue the fight against child poverty. Later, Prime Minister Tony Blair will answer questions sent by the public via text and e-mail.
 
 Analysing Mr Brown's position before the speech, BBC correspondent James Hardy said Mr Brown would draw "sharp dividing lines" with the Conservatives for the forthcoming election campaign. He would contrast Labour's plan to invest £60bn in services with a Tory plan to cut spending by £35bn. "Mr Brown will lay out his credentials as a reforming chancellor determined to take on and beat the Asian tiger economies which increasingly dominate world trade," our correspondent said.
 
 On Friday night, Mr Brown confirmed he would not make any tax commitments until the Labour manifesto had been published after the Budget, expected in March. But commentators will listen to his speech closely for hints on whether, as the Conservatives claim, he plans to raise tax after the election. The Tories accuse Labour of raising taxes 66 times since coming to power in 1997.
 
 Following the chancellor's keynote speech, the prime minister will face interactive questioning from ordinary voters on Saturday. Mr Blair is thought to be deliberately putting himself on the line in a bid to engage the electorate ahead of an expected May election. Capital Radio DJ Margherita Taylor will select questions to put to him from thousands e-mailed and sent by text. The prime minister's enthusiasm for the job remains undimmed, Alan Milburn, Labour's election strategist told Radio 4's Today programme on Saturday. Mr Blair has "the same passion and the same commitments for the job" as when Labour came to power in 1997, he said.
 
 And he confirmed Mr Blair's insistence that no poll date had yet been set. He said: "I'm the General Election co-ordinator and I don't know, and Tony has not made up his mind." On Friday, the prime minister completed a whistle-stop tour of England, during which he unveiled his party's six pre-election pledges. Starting in London, he visited marginal constituencies pledging to build on what he said were Labour's achievements on the economy, crime, education and public services. The Conservatives and Lib Dems said the pledges - set to underpin Labour's election campaign - were "worthless".
llama3.2:1b: Gordon Brown delivers a speech at Labour's spring conference, praising his party's economic record and vowing to maintain stability if elected.
He will also focus on addressing child poverty.
llama3.2:3b: Gordon Brown delivered a speech at Labour's spring conference, stating his pride in the party's economic record and commitment to stability, as well as helping young people buy homes and fighting child poverty.
He vowed not to make tax commitments until after the Budget in March.
The prime minister Tony Blair will answer public questions via text and e-mail on Saturday.

He highlighted the government's achievements on the economy, pledged to help young people buy homes, and promised to continue combating child poverty.
He will contrast Labour's investment plans with Conservative spending cuts during the campaign.
Brown has not made tax commitments until after the budget in March, but his speech may give clues about future tax policies.
Prime Minister Tony Blair will engage in public questioning via text and email on Saturday, aiming to connect with voters before an expected May election.
The prime minister insists no poll date has been set.

He promises not to commit to any tax decisions until the manifesto is published after the Budget in March.
Prime Minister Tony Blair will answer questions from voters on Saturday through text and email.

He pledged to invest £60bn in services, contrasting this with the Conservatives' plan to cut spending by £35bn.
Brown confirmed he would not make tax commitments until after the March Budget but commentators will closely follow his speech for hints on potential future tax increases.

Following his keynote address, Prime Minister Tony Blair is set to engage directly with voters via interactive questioning and pledges, including those aimed at improving economy, crime, education, and public services in marginal constituencies.
Despite a tour of England unveiling these six pre-election promises, the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats criticized them as "worthless."

Mr Blair has "the same commitment to the people of this country that Tony Blair had before the war", he said.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Gordon Brown will deliver a speech to Labour's spring conference, discussing his plan for the upcoming general election.
He aims to focus on economic reform and oppose the Conservative Party.
He plans to work with young people in Gateshead and publish Labour’s manifesto by March before committing to tax commitments.
James Hardy noted he will lay out credentials as a reforming Chancellor targeting Asian economies.

Tony Blair is expected to answer questions from voters, focusing on election campaign efforts, including economic issues, while his emphasis on voter numbers aligns with Labour's focus on economic and social sectors.
Margherita Taylor will interview him based on emails, and Alan Milburn highlighted Blair’s commitment similar to Labour’s 1997 days.

The text highlights key ideas and details from the text material, including Brown's announcements about tax commitments after the election, his commitment to investing £60bn in services and a "cut [of] spendings by 35% for Tories" (emphasis mine).
Despite being described as "sharp dividing lines" with the Conservatives, the article speculates that Brown will highlight his own economic credentials while campaigning.
It also notes that the prime minister faces interactive questioning on Saturday from Capital Radio DJ Margheritta Taylor and is committed to staying on the job despite a potential May election.

Key highlights included investment in public services, tax cuts, and a focus on reducing child poverty.
He also rejected calls for a change to the voting system.

Although Brown had confirmed he wouldn't make any tax commitments until the Labour manifesto was published after the Budget in March, speculation continued regarding whether he planned to raise taxes after the election.
